description: From Middle English falwe, from Old English fealh (“fallow land”), from Proto-West Germanic *falgu (compare Saterland Frisian falge, Dutch valg, German Felge), from Proto-Indo-European *polḱéh₂ (“arable land”) (compare Gaulish olca, Russian полоса́ (polosá)).

adjectives.description: fallow (comparative more fallow, superlative most fallow)

entries.meaning: (of agricultural land) Ploughed but left unseeded for more than one planting season.
(of agricultural land) Left unworked and uncropped for some amount of time.

examples: a fallow period in one's career

entries.meaning: (agriculture, uncountable) Ground ploughed and harrowed but left unseeded for one year.
The ploughing or tilling of land, without sowing it for a season.
examples: By a complete summer fallow, land is rendered tender and mellow. The fallow gives it a better tilth than can be given by a fallow crop.

description: From Middle English falowen, falwen, from Old English fealgian (“to fallow; break up land”), from Proto-West Germanic *falgōn (“to fallow”). Cognate with Dutch valgen (“to plow lightly; fallow”), German Low German falgen (“to till; dig a hole”).

verbs.description: fallow (third-person singular simple present fallows, present participle fallowing, simple past and past participle fallowed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make land fallow for agricultural purposes.

description: From Middle English falwe, from Old English fealu, from Proto-Germanic *falwaz (compare West Frisian feal, Dutch vaal, German falb, fahl), from Proto-Indo-European *polwos (compare Lithuanian pal̃vas (“sallow, wan”), Russian половый (polovyj, “wan, light yellow”), Serbo-Croatian plâv (“blond, blue”), Ancient Greek πολιός (poliós, “grey”)), from Proto-Indo-European *pelH- (“pale, gray”).

adjectives.description: fallow (comparative more fallow, superlative most fallow)

entries.meaning: (color) Of a pale red or yellow, light brown; dun.
